compliance.Analysis: The contract lacks explicit mention of the lawful basis for processing personal data. This is a critical GDPR requirement.
The contract doesn't detail how data subject rights (access, rectification, erasure, etc.) will be handled or how DSARs will be processed. This is a major GDPR omission.
Section 6.1(d) mentions appropriate technical and organizational measures but lacks specifics. The level of detail is insufficient for robust compliance.
The contract doesn't address the engagement of subprocessors, their approval by the controller, or the flow-down of GDPR obligations. This is a significant risk.
The contract lacks a clause mandating notification of data breaches to the controller within 72 hours and cooperation on investigation and reporting.
The contract is missing provisions for data retention periods and data deletion upon contract termination. This is a crucial GDPR requirement.
The contract doesn't address the transfer of personal data outside the EU/EEA or specify any safeguards used. This is a major GDPR concern.
While there's an indemnity clause (Section 9), it doesn't specifically address liability for GDPR violations or apportionment of fines. The scope is limited.
The contract outlines termination procedures (Section 4), but doesn't explicitly detail data deletion or return upon termination, which needs further clarification.
The contract lacks a specific clause requiring cooperation with DPAs during audits or investigations. While implied, explicit mention is needed.
While the contract mentions DORA and ICT security, it lacks specifics on the framework used for managing ICT risks. A more detailed description is needed.
The contract mentions SLAs in Section 2.2, indicating their inclusion, although the specifics are in a separate exhibit.
Section 6.2(d) explicitly addresses incident reporting and cooperation in resolution.
The contract mentions cooperation on DORA compliance, but lacks explicit details on the testing procedures and frequency.
No mention of BCPs or how the service provider will ensure business continuity in case of disruptions.
Section 6 details GDPR and DORA compliance regarding data protection, including technical and organizational measures.
The contract doesn't address the process for approving subcontractors, a key aspect of DORA compliance.
Section 4 outlines clear termination clauses, including procedures for data return and transition.
Section 6.1(f) grants the client audit rights to ensure compliance with GDPR and, by extension, relevant DORA requirements.
The contract doesn't explicitly address the designation of the service provider as critical or non-critical, a crucial aspect for DORA compliance.
The contract mentions "robust ICT security measures" but lacks specifics on the implemented controls.
While late payment penalties are specified, there are no penalties explicitly defined for non-compliance with DORA requirements.
